repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - National Human Development
            Initiative (INDH) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the National Human
            Development Initiative (INDH) Project for Morocco were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was moderate to significant; Bank
            performance: was moderately satisfactory; and borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned includes: the valuable lessons drawn from the
            implementation of first INDH are based on continuous
            learning and dialogue between the Government, the Bank and
            other partners, and are supplemented by contributions from a
            broad spectrum of stakeholders through stakeholder
            workshops. The overall conclusions are presented here, but
            given the need for intensive learning and applicability to
            second INDH, annex two and annex six contain more detailed
            lessons learned in all areas of the project. INDH has shown
            that new participatory approaches can be put in place
            rapidly. In an environment with a history of top-down,
            centralized decision making, implanting a culture of
            participatory diagnostic and programming and real
            empowerment of poor communities poses many policy and
            institutional challenges. The first five year phase of the
            INDH has succeeded, with strong government commitment,
            adequate resource allocation and good technical support, in
            building capacity in governance and support structures,
            establishing participatory approaches, and showing what
            improvements are needed. Further, INDH has also demonstrated
            that large numbers of sub-projects can be implemented in a
            very short period. Despite the risks, a well-designed and
            supported program can begin from almost nothing and achieve
            high levels of implementation in a very short time, provided
            that adequate supporting measures are in place.

Morocco - National Human Development
            Initiative (INDH) Project

repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - Implementing an ambitious social
            and economic transformation agenda

abstracts.cdata!:
Morocco's sound economic management
            in recent years has yielded strong growth and investment
            grade status and it is weathering the negative impacts of
            the global crisis impressively well. Morocco is now
            addressing persistent social problems by reducing absolute
            poverty rates, investing in human capital through quality
            education, expanding access to drinking water, and linking
            rural areas to markets through investment in roads.

repnme.cdata!:
Morocco - National Initiative for Human
            Development Support Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The National Initiative for Human
            Development Support Project for Morocco will assist the
            Government in improving inclusiveness, accountability and
            transparency of decision making and implementation processes
            at the local level in order to enhance use of social and
            economic infrastructure and services by poor and vulnerable
            groups. The Mid Term Review (MTR) for the project was held
            in November 2008. At this time it was found that several
            indicators proved redundant and the progress they were meant
            to measure could be monitored with fewer indicators. In
            addition, the project's indicators in the results
            framework were not directly related to the project
            development objective (PDO) nor to the project's
            components, and some target values were unrealistic. A
            request to restructure the project was finally received from
            the Ministry of the Economy and Finance on 25 December,
            2009. The long time that elapsed between the MTR and the
            formal request for restructuring is due to the consultations
            necessary among key stakeholders in Morocco as well as with
            other donors involved with the project. Given the high
            visibility of the project, it was also necessary to ensure
            that it was generally understood that the restructuring does
            not reflect problems with the project per se, but rather a
            need for more meaningful indicators to monitor the project.

display_title.display_title:
Morocco - National Initiative for
            Human Development Support Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) :
            Data sheet

            Initiative (INDH) Project for Morocco will assist the
            Government in improving inclusiveness, accountability and
            transparency of decision making and implementation processes
            at the local level in order to enhance use of social and
            economic infrastructure and services by poor and vulnerable
            groups.  The project is composed of the following
            components: component one - alleviate poverty in rural
            areas; component two: alleviate social exclusion in urban
            areas; component three - alleviate extreme vulnerability;
            and component four - mainstreaming INDH governance
            mechanisms and strengthening of institutional capacity.
